metadata.case_name: Raghubar Dayal Jai Prakash & Ors. v. Union of India & Ors.

facts.text: Petitions filed under Art. 32 for enforcement of fundamental rights challenging constitutional validity of Forward Contracts Regulation Act, 1952, notification dated February 11, 1959 under s.15 applying Act to gur, and simultaneous notification fixing price for settlement of subsisting forward contracts.

Petitioner Raghubar Dayal Jai Prakash, firm at Meerut, carrying business of purchase and sale of gur and other commodities, entered into forward contracts for purchase of 29,600 maunds of gur outstanding on February 11, 1959, deposited amount and special margin under bye-laws of Kaisergunj Beopar Co. P. Ltd., Meerut.

Kaisergunj Beopar Co. P. Ltd., Meerut, company formed by traders to regulate forward transactions in gur among members and declare settlement rates; not recognised under the Act on date of notification.

Notification under s.15 dated February 11, 1959, applied provisions to gur with immediate effect, rendering petitioner's forward contracts illegal and void, deemed closed out on that date, differences payable at rates specified in another notification, causing petitioner loss of Rs. 48,000.
Forward trading in gur banned post-war by Sugar Gur Future Trading Prohibition Order, 1951 under Essential Supplies Act, 1946; ban removed January 7, 1954; Act not applied to gur until 1959.
Forward Markets Commission in May 1957 recommended recognition of associations and notification under s.15 for gur; Government rejected in January 17, 1958 resolution, no strong justification.
End of 1958, hectic speculative activity; gur prices at Hapur rose 37% from mid-Nov to mid-Feb 1959 vs. 0.15% sugar and 1.5% khandsari; led to reconsideration and s.15 notification on Feb 11, 1959.
Notification under s.16 fixed closing rates as average of closing rates in forward markets during three months preceding Feb 11, 1959.
No associations recognised before Feb 11, 1959; later recognised in June 1959 at Hapur, Meerut, Agra, Muzaffarnagar, Delhi; petitioners members of these associations.
Bans under s.17 on minor woodgrains July 17, 1958 and khandsari sugar July 18, 1958 increased speculation in gur; prices at Hapur from Rs.11.98/maund Jan 17, 1958 to Rs.16.27 Feb 11, 1959.

legal_issues.text: Constitutional validity of operative provisions of Forward Contracts Regulation Act, 1952.
Validity of notification dated February 11, 1959 under s.15 bringing gur within purview of Act.
Validity of notification dated February 11, 1959 under s.16 fixing price for settlement of subsisting forward contracts in gur.

petitioner_arguments.text: Sections 5,6,10 infringe Art.19(1)(c) by interfering with freedom to form associations, internal management, rules and bye-laws; restrictions not based on public order or morality.
S.15 requires prior recognition of association; notification invalid without it; issuing without recognition unreasonable restriction on Art.19(1)(g).
S.15 confers unguided arbitrary power violating Art.14; selects commodity and time arbitrarily.
S.15 retrospectively invalidates contracts, unreasonable restriction on Art.19(1)(f) and (g) as right to contract benefits is property/trade right.
S.16 vests arbitrary power to fix prices without guidance, excessive delegation or violates Art.14.

respondent_arguments.text: Forward trading regulation legitimate; no compulsion for recognition, voluntary; control via associations advances policy.
Urgent situation due to speculation justified immediate s.15 notification before recognition; prices rigged, average of 3 months fair.

court_reasoning.text: Ss.5,6,10 do not infringe Art.19(1)(c); recognition voluntary, no guaranteed right to recognition; regulation of forward trading legitimate, control via associations policy choice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Restrictions only on recognised associations; Parliament could have used official agency.

court_reasoning.text: S.15 does not require prior recognised association; traders cannot defeat Act by not forming one; urgent speculation justified immediate action, reasonable under Art.19(6).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Enquiries for recognition take time; no mala fides.

court_reasoning.text: S.15 not arbitrary under Art.14; Forward Markets Commission advises on variable factors like production, demand; public interest in stable prices for essential commodity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Guidance from policy and machinery in Ch.II.

court_reasoning.text: Retrospective effect on contracts not per se unreasonable under Art.19(1)(f),(g); no constitutional bar like US contract clause; reasonableness depends on circumstances.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Test per V.G. Row case: urgency, evil remedied.

court_reasoning.text: S.16 price fixation guided by reasonableness implicit, like Essential Commodities Act; average 3 months fair given rigged spot prices from speculation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No mechanical spot price; prevents manipulation.

holdings.text: Provisions of Forward Contracts Regulation Act, 1952, including ss.5,6,10,15,16 constitutionally valid; do not violate Arts.14,19(1)(c),(f),(g).
Notifications under ss.15,16 dated Feb 11, 1959 valid; action reasonable in circumstances.
Price fixation under s.16 reasonable and valid.

precedents_cited.relevance: Test of reasonableness: nature of right, purpose, urgency, conditions.

outcome.summary: Court upheld constitutional validity of Forward Contracts Regulation Act, 1952 and notifications under ss.15,16 dated Feb 11, 1959 applying to gur; rejected all challenges; petitions dismissed.

key_quotes.text: "Forward trading involves speculation about the future, but not all forms of forward trading could be considered as either unnecessary or undesirable for the efficient functioning of anything but the most primitive economy."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains economic role and need for regulation of forward trading.

key_quotes.text: "The restriction imposed by s.6 of the Act is for the purpose of recognition and no association is compelled to apply to the Government for recognition under that Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "It is important in this context to bear in mind that the test of reasonableness... should all enter into the judicial verdict."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Cites V.G. Row on reasonableness under Art.19.
